Great game, originally started off as a Unreal Tournament mod now made into a commercial game with tons of fun to be had. Recommend you play with a friend to level up or atleast solo offline till you level up to level 4 because on hard and suicidal its really tough to play regardless of your aim. Oh and ill save you the trouble the end boss The Patriarch has one of the most epic sound tracks ever its made by zYnthetic and its called "Abandon All" go youtube it now!!! :D

This is probably my favorite "zombie" shooter. More skill and teamplay needed then some other zombie games. a good amount of weapons, awesome metal music, and plenty of maps. Game is great with a group of friends. Can play with more then just four.

Killing floor is an excellent choice for a Zombie survival game. At first when i bought this game i thought it was an okayish game but when i know my loadoat and was focusing on achievements i find this game fun to play, however i perfer more of Left 4 Dead than this. This game also gives a lot of realism with the fact that you have no crosshair and your character doesnt have experience with a gun but as you level up you get more comfortable with your weaponary.  Its a pity that this game was programed with simple programing actions in the unreal engine but its an exception.  This takes place in Europe and dont be thinking this is all about nazi zombies its modern zombies, and also its more gentlemen like if you say euros (Europian money) instead of dollars (American money)  because every time you kill a zombie you get euros so stop saying its dollars. So if your in the mood for a new zombie game then this is a fine choice.

At first I hated this game and couldn't understand the appeal of the repetitive game style. Eventually I warmed up to it and got used to the money managment and perk strategies. The game can be very fun when you get a good group cooperating together. The only part I would change is to add a shove/melee to the guns so that you can still push them back if you have too many on you at once.
Edit: I have changed my overal opinion of the game mostly based on the community. Many online players are rude and no longer play to have fun. I would like to say this is a minority of players, but it has been steadily increasing to most servers. It also starts to become a slow and boring grinding game once you get up to level 4-6 on your skill perks.

Just kill zombie-ish creatures in survival mode? That's it? Booooooring! I completely miss the point. This is just a waste of time: no puzzle, no story, no fun. Just kill waves of creatures, run to the shop and purchase more powerful weapons to survive next round. On top of that, game crashes at startup real bad (program stopped working) if you select highest video options and you have to reinstall it from scratch.
I paid like $5 for the game and would gladly get my money back.
Put your money elsewhere, Killing Floor has no replay value and actually has no value whatsoever.

I don't want to call it a ripoff of L4D2, but it draws extremely close to that. On top of that, it's rather unintuitive and the perk system is just dumb. If the perks were session- or character-specific or something, it would make a minor amount more sense, but it would still be pretty dumb. It's a lot like a huge cluster of "kill 100 enemies" "kill 500 enemies" "kill 1,000 enemies" achiev-I mean, progress markers.

The game itself is not too bad, however; it plays much like a slightly-less-polished L4D2 with the added concept of strict waves and the ability to buy weapons in between.

I haven't played more than ten minutes of this game, but I don't want to, because I am so dissapointed by how fundamentally un-fun I find that its' mechanics are. You move like you're on the moon, the bread-and-butter combat system is aim-down-sights for NO REASON (it quite works against the overall game), and the DLC is a negative value-add mess. Its' art style is derivative of many better games, in all the wrong ways. This game is a ripoff! It had been outpaced by so many competitors.

I had a ball with Left 4 Dead, and this game was better in so many ways. The gore and the blood was insane and the screeches of wave after wave of satisfying zombies :3 kept me on my toes forever as I played into the wee hours of the night afraid they'd get me at dawn o.O.... A very fun game and gets extremely more so when you add friends to the mix... Definetly reccomend it for ans of the L4D franchise and for any who love to just plain kill some zombies once in awhile XD

A fun and rather simplistic Shoot em up, spray and pray zombie survival game. Its based on waves and between each wave you get to spend your money you get by killing zombies at a shop to buy armor, weapons, etc. Which weapons you buy will probably depend on your class. Its a fun game to pick up and play, but it doesn't really have a story mode. It has a level system so that adds a bit of fun to it, but make sure you have friends with the game too, its an okay game, but its MUCH funner with some friends.

This game is a great alternative to Valve's Left 4 Dead series. The locations, the atmosphere, it all just gives you right feeling of the horror. And the british accent the survivors speak with makes it even better. There is alot of different kinds of weapons, so there is way to play for everyone. Each kind of specimen have their own ability unique to only them, wich makes cooperation very important if you want to survive.

Soft yes,

Who would have thought that a UT2004 engine game would have been this successful (1 million+ sales) in this age? It may come up shy graphically but on gameplay, it makes up for that with nice wave-based co-op Z-killing. Unlike Left 4 Dead, this is a leveled class-based shooter with a kill-bounty system. With clear roles defined through the classes, the nuance and dynamic of gameplay is both deep enough for thorough replay and relatively easy to grasp as a group from the get go. Levelling can create tiers of mismatched player groups, though.

Since release in 2009, not only has Tripwire rolled out updates with new weapons and tweaks, as well as keep the DLC simple optional content (player models) rather than gameplay critical, the community behind the game has cranked out a whole load of maps that can be (for the better part) included in the whitelist (maps recognised by KF so you can advance your class). Recommended to anyone who can look past the dated graphics and see the gameplay.

The pound was a unit of account in Anglo-Saxon England, equal to 240 silver pennies and equivalent to one pound weight of silver. It evolved into the modern British currency, the pound sterling.
The accounting system of 4 farthings = 1 penny, 12 pence = 1 shilling, 20 shillings = 1 pound was adopted from that introduced by Charlemagne to the Frankish Empire (see French livre).
The origins of sterling lie in the reign of King Offa of Mercia, (757‚Äì96) who introduced the silver penny. It copied the denarius of the new currency system of Charlemagne's Frankish Empire. As in the Carolingian system, 240 pennies weighed 1 pound (corresponding to Charlemagne's libra), with the shilling corresponding to Charlemagne's solidus and equal to 12d. At the time of the penny's introduction, it weighed 22.5 troy grains of fine silver (32 tower grains; about 1.5 g), indicating that the Mercian pound weighed 5,400 troy grains.
